item.title: Splitgate 2 Launches Into 1.0 This Week
item.content:encoded:
https://gameinformer.com/2025/06/03/splitgate-2-launches-into-10-this-week

1047 Games has revealed that its portal-infused Halo-like shooter, Splitgate 2, will launch into 1.0 this week after a short beta period last month. More specifically, Splitgate 2 will launch on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and PC via the Windows Store and Epic Games Store on Friday, June 6.

Alongside this news, 1047 Games says it has a “major surprise” in store for Summer Game Fest, which takes place this Friday at 2 p.m. PT/5 p.m. ET. The developer says this reveal is the “biggest part” of Splitgate 2.

To celebrate the release date news, the team has released a trailer about being an ace in the futuristic portal-y world of Splitgate 2. Check it out below:

“Would-be aces can also jump into Splitgate 2’s final open beta, going on now through launch, to get a taste of some of what the futuristic portal shooter will offer on June 6 – a metric ton of maps, weapons, and modes are all there for the taking,” a press release reads.

Like the previous betas, it’s free to hop into this one (and the full 1.0 game will be free, as well). Plus, there’s a Beta Battlepass available to get some unlockable cosmetics early in your Splitgate 2 playtime. 1047 Games says progression will not reset when Splitgate 2 launches.

Are you going to hop into Splitgate 2 this week? Let us know in the comments below!

item.title: PlayStation Announces A State Of Play Will Air Tomorrow, June 4
item.content:encoded:
https://gameinformer.com/2025/06/03/playstation-announces-a-state-of-play-will-air-tomorrow-june-4

This morning, PlayStation announced that it would be airing a 40-minute State of Play tomorrow, Wednesday, June 4. While we were all set for showcases from Summer Game Fest on Friday and Xbox on Sunday, this is a surprise (but a welcome one). Sony's involvement in the yearly rush of summer showcases has been up in the air since it backed out of E3 in 2019, and now all the major players are accounted for (save Nintendo, but it has plans of its own this week).

The showcase will air at 2 PM PT/5 PM ET and will include "news and updates on must-play games coming to PS5," according to the PS Blog. It will be available to watch on YouTube and Twitch.

Aside from that, we don't have any specific details on the games to be featured, but given the time of year, it's fair to assume we'll see some big titles from Sony's upcoming catalogue. Ghost of Yōtei, which launches this October, is perhaps the most obvious candidate, but there are other PlayStation studios we haven't heard from in a while, including Insomniac, which is working on a Wolverine game, and Sony Santa Monica, which we haven't heard much from since God of War Ragnarök's Valhalla DLC. 

To catch the rest of the summer showcases live, check out our big 2025 livestream schedule, giving times for everything from Summer Game Fest to the Wholesome Direct.

What do you hope to see from this showcase? Let us know in the comments!

item.title: Hi-Fi Rush Developer Tango Gameworks Officially Relaunches And Is Making A New Action Game
item.content:encoded:
https://gameinformer.com/2025/06/02/hi-fi-rush-developer-tango-gameworks-officially-relaunches-and-is-making-a-new-action

In May 2024, Microsoft abruptly shut down Tango Gameworks, the studio behind Hi-Fi Rush, Ghostwire: Tokyo, and The Evil Within series. However, its demise was short-lived, as publisher Krafton acquired the studio and the rights to the Hi-Fi Rush IP a few months later in August. Today, Tango is officially back in operation and is gearing up for its next title.

Tango has reopened its Tokyo office, launched a new website, and unveiled a redesigned company logo. The full version is above, and the simplified version is below.

In a blog post, Tango states the logo is meant to “encapsulate the studio’s vision as a 'creative workshop': a place where creators have ownership of their work, and their individual contributions come together into games that feel ‘handmade with soul.’”

Creative Director John Johanas remains part of the team, and the studio is hiring for a mysterious new action game with openings in nearly every department. Given that Tango has retained the Hi-Fi Rush IP (Microsoft still owns the rights to The Evil Within and Ghostwire: Tokyo), a sequel to the 2023 hit could be in the cards, but it will likely be a good while before we learn what form this new project takes. 

It's rare to see shuttered studios get a second lease on life, so we're pleased to see Tango Gameworks back on its feet and look forward to seeing what it has in store. For more on the studio, check out our review of its last game, Hi-Fi Rush, here.
